body.p:
Looking back in history, it's easy to see that many of society's most important technologies are attributable to advances in photonics. In telecommunications, for example, the past decade has seen the Internet reach all corners of the globe, thanks to high-speed optical networking and wavelength-division multiplexing.

Photonics research has a valuable role to play in improving the performance of solar cells.

In the future, another area in which photonics is likely to have a similar impact is that of energy generation — particularly photovoltaic solar-cell technology. As nations come under pressure to reduce their carbon emissions and adopt 'green' forms of energy generation, it is expected that the deployment of solar cells will increase significantly over the next 10–20 years, although this will be only a small part of the solution to the complex problem of energy generation. Indeed, there are already signs of increasing activity, with major suppliers of silicon solar cells in Japan, Germany and China investing in scaling up their manufacturing capabilities, and an increasing number of photonics researchers working in the field.

An interesting question from a photonics point of view is whether crystalline silicon solar cells will remain the dominant technology in the long-term, or whether one of the many competing technologies will take over. There's certainly no shortage of contenders, be it cells composed of cadmium telluride, copper indium gallium selenide or amorphous silicon, multi-junction cells or cells based on semiconducting polymers, dye-sensitized designs or quantum dots. Indeed, intense research is taking place in all of these areas, with each approach having its own unique set of advantages and challenges, and each inspiring new commercial ventures.

At a more fundamental level, photonics research has a valuable role to play in improving the performance of solar cells — power conversion efficiencies in particular — through various means. One approach is to expand their spectral response deeper into the ultraviolet and infrared through schemes such as quantum cutting, which splits high-energy, short-wavelength ultraviolet photons into two lower energy ones, and two-photon absorption, which combines the energy from two low-energy photons in the infrared. Another approach being explored is the use of surface texturing to minimize cell reflectivity and plasmonic nanostructures to help trap and utilize as much of the incoming light as possible.

In recognition of the growing importance of solar energy, Nature Photonics is organizing a three-day event on the topic of photovoltaics. “The Nature Photonics Technology Conference — Future Perspectives on Photovoltaics” will take place in Tokyo, Japan from 19 to 21 October 2010. The event follows in the style of our first successful conference in 2007 (which discussed the future of optical communication), and will feature approximately 20 invited plenary-style talks by world experts from both academia and industry to discuss the current status of various photovoltaic technologies and the future challenges and opportunities that such technologies may face. The event will be free to attend, but registration is required. For more information please visit the event website at www.natureasia.com/en/photovoltaics.

Makoto Konagai from the Tokyo Institute of Technology has kindly agreed to act as chairman of the conference's technical advisory board. Several keynote speakers have also been confirmed, including Alan Heeger from the University of California at Santa Barbara, USA, and Michael Grätzel from the École Polytechnic Fédérale de Lausanne in Switzerland. Alan Heeger shared the 2000 Nobel Prize for Chemistry with Hideki Shirakawa and Alan McDiarmid for their work on semiconducting polymers, which are now being commercialized as a new type of flexible, plastic solar cell. Fellow speaker Michael Grätzel invented the dye-sensitized solar cell, which is another promising emerging technology.

The event will also feature a co-located exhibition that many firms will be using to showcase their photovoltaic technology. Sharp, Kyocera, Mitsubishi Electric, the New Energy and Industrial Technology Development Organization (NEDO) and the National Institute of Advanced Industrial Science and Technology (AIST) have recently signed up as sponsors of the event, and we would like to acknowledge their support. A full list of speakers and a detailed programme will be hosted on the conference website as soon as they are finalized, so please check back on a regular basis. A detailed report describing the event will be produced afterwards and distributed along with Nature Photonics towards the end of the year.

If you are interested in receiving a thought-provoking insight into the future evolution of solar energy and the various technologies involved, then please do come along to experience the talks and debates first hand.
